page.title: 5.7.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will determine whether situations are characterized by exponential growth or by exponential decay given real-world scenarios of descriptions and graphs.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Use graphs to compare and contrast situations that involve exponential decay.
  • Use information from a graph to write an equation that represents exponential decay.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 5.7.1: Patterns in Real Numbers
  • 5.7.2: Comparing Graphs
    • 5.7.2: Self Check 
  • 5.7.3: Describing Graphs 
    • 5.7.3: Self Check 
  • 5.7.4: Quantities that Change Exponentially

After that, youâ€™ll practice and review.

  • 5.7.5: Practice
  • 5.7.6: Lesson Summary

answer.answer_text: Next

page.title: 5.7.1: Patterns in Real Numbers
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

In the table, find as many patterns as you can. Use one or more patterns to help you complete the table. Be prepared to explain your reasoning.


fraction

\(\frac12\)

\(\frac14\)

\(\frac18\)

\(\frac{1}{16}\)

\(\frac{1}{32}\)

decimal

0.5

0.25

0.125

a.___

b.___

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

a. 0.0625

  • Each number is half of the previous number. We can find the next number by multiplying the current number by \(\frac12\) or by 0.5, or by dividing by 2.
  • The non-zero digits of the decimals are powers of 5 (\(5^1\), \(5^2\), \(5^3\), etc.), and each time there is an additional decimal place.
  • 0.5 can be written as \(\frac{5}{10}\), 0.25 as \(\frac{25}{100}\), and 0.125 as \(\frac{125}{1,000}\). The numerators are powers of 5, and the denominators are powers of 10, so the next two numbers are \(\frac{5^4}{10^4}\), which is \(\frac{65}{10,000}\) or 0.0625, and \(\frac{5^5}{10^5}\), which is \(\frac{3,125}{100,000}\) or 0.03125.

b. 0.03125

  • Each number is half of the previous number. We can find the next number by multiplying the current number by \(\frac12\) or by 0.5, or by dividing by 2.
  • The non-zero digits of the decimals are powers of 5 (\(5^1\), \(5^2\), \(5^3\), etc.), and each time there is an additional decimal place.
  • 0.5 can be written as \(\frac{5}{10}\), 0.25 as \(\frac{25}{100}\), and 0.125 as \(\frac{125}{1,000}\). The numerators are powers of 5, and the denominators are powers of 10, so the next two numbers are \(\frac{5^4}{10^4}\), which is \(\frac{65}{10,000}\) or 0.0625, and \(\frac{5^5}{10^5}\), which is \(\frac{3,125}{100,000}\) or 0.03125.
  • The denominators in the fractions are powers of 2.

Next

page.title: 5.7.2: Comparing Graphs
page.contents:
Activity

The value of some cell phones changes exponentially after initial release. Here are graphs showing the depreciation of two phones 1, 2, and 3 years after they were released.

Phone A

Phone B

  


  1. Which phone is more expensive to buy when it is first released?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Phone A costs $1,000 and Phone B costs $840, so Phone A is more expensive.



  1. How does the value of each phone change with every passing year?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Phone A is depreciating more quickly than Phone B.



  1. Which one is falling in value more quickly? Explain or show how you know.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Phone A loses $400 in the first year, which is \(\frac25\) (or 0.4 or 40%) of the original value. It loses $240 in the second year, which is \(\frac25\) (or 0.4 or 40%) of $600. Phone B loses $210 in the first year, which is \(\frac14\) (or 0.25 or 25%) of the original value, and $157.50 in the second year, which is \(\frac14\) of $630.



  1. If the phones continue to depreciate by the same factor each year, what will the value of each phone be 4 years after its initial release?
    1. Enter your answer for Phone A.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(\frac{3}{5} \cdot 216=129.60\)



    1. Enter your answer for Phone B.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(\frac{3}{4} \cdot (354.38) \approx 265.79\)



  1. For each cell phone, write an equation that relates the value of the phone in dollars to the years since release, \(t\). Use \(v\) for the value of Phone A and \(w\) for the value of Phone B.
    1. Enter your answer for Phone A.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\( v=1,000 \cdot (\frac{3}{5})^t\) 



    1. Enter your answer for Phone B.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\( w=840 \cdot (\frac{3}{4})^t\)



Making a Real-World Connection

When given data, it is not always clear how to best model it. In this case, we were told the value of the cell phones was changing exponentially. Suppose, however, we were instead just given the initial values of the cell phones when released and the values after each of the first three years.

  1. Use technology to compute the best fit line for each cell phone. Round any numbers to the nearest dollar.
    1. Enter your answer for Phone A.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(v=933âˆ’259t\)


    1. Enter your answer for Phone B.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\( w=816âˆ’161t\)


  1. Explain why, in this situation, an exponential model might be more appropriate than the linear model you just created.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

A linear model would quickly lead to negative phone values. For example, Phone A would cost about â€“$103 four years after its initial release. It makes more sense that the phone would lose a fraction of its value each year.

page.title: 5.7.2: Self Check
page.contents: For the following exercise, consider this scenario: For each year \(t\), the population of trees in Forest A is represented by the function \(A(t)=115(1.025)^t\), (red line). In a neighboring forest, Forest B, the population of the same type of tree is represented by the function \(B(t)=82(1.029)^t\), (blue line). Looking at the graph provided, which forest had a greater number of trees initially?

answer.answer_text: Both forests started with the same number of trees.
answer.response: Incorrect. Letâ€™s try again a different way: The initial value of an exponential function is the same as its \(y\)-intercept on the graph, so a higher \(y\)-intercept is a greater initial value. The answer is Forest A, because it starts higher on the \(y\)-axis.

answer.answer_text: Forest A, because it starts higher on the \(y\)-axis.
answer.response: Thatâ€™s correct! Check yourself: The initial value of an exponential function is the same as its \(y\)-intercept on the graph, so a higher \(y\)-intercept is a greater initial value.

answer.answer_text: Forest A, because it has a greater growth rate.
answer.response: Incorrect. Letâ€™s try again a different way: The initial value of an exponential function is the same as its \(y\)-intercept on the graph, not the growth rate. The answer is Forest A, because it starts higher on the \(y\)-axis.

answer.answer_text: Forest B, because it has a greater growth rate.
answer.response: Incorrect. Letâ€™s try again a different way: Forest B does have a greater growth rate, but the growth rate does not determine the initial value. The initial value of an exponential function is the same as its \(y\)-intercept on the graph. The answer is Forest A, because it starts higher on the \(y\)-axis.

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 5.7.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Analyzing \(a\) and \(b\) in the Exponential Function \(y=ab^x\)

  1. Which graph has the largest value for \(b\)?
  2. Which graph has the smallest value for \(b\)?
  3. Which graph has the largest value for \(a\)?
  4. Which graph has the smallest value for \(a\)?

When using the form \(y=ab^x\), it is important to remember that \(a\) is the initial value, or the \(y\)-intercept, and \(b\) is the growth factor. The growth factor reflects an exponential growth function when the value is greater than one. The growth factor reflects an exponential decay function when the value is between zero and one.

For question 1, you are looking for the largest growth factor, which would mean an exponential growth function that is increasing the most rapidly. First, identify the graphs that reflect exponential growth, which would be D, E, and F, and then decide which is the steepest. Graph D increases much faster than both graphs E and F.

For question 2, you are looking for the smallest growth factor, or the exponential decay function that is decaying slower than the other graphs. The decay graphs are A, B, and C, and graph A is decaying much more slowly than the other graphs

For question 3, you are looking for the largest initial value or \(y\)-intercept. This could be with a growth or decay function; it just needs to cross the \(y\)-axis higher than the other graphs. Graph C has the highest \(a\) value.

For question 4, you are looking for the smallest initial value or \(y\)-intercept. This could be a growth or decay function; it just needs to cross the \(y\)-axis lower than the other graphs. Graph F has the lowest \(a\) value.

Try It: Analyzing \(a\) and \(b\) in the Exponential Function \(y=ab^x\)

  1. Which graphs represent exponential growth?
  2. Which graphs represent exponential decay?
  3. Which graph has the highest value for \(b\)?
  4. Which graph has the highest value for \(a\)?

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answers:

Here is how to analyze and compare graphs of exponential functions:

  1. Graphs indicate exponential growth if they are increasing from left to right. Graphs D, E, and F represent exponential growth.
  2. Graphs indicate exponential decay if they are decreasing from left to right. Graphs A, B, and C represent exponential decay.
  3. Graph E has the highest value of \(b\), or growth rate, since it is increasing faster than graphs D and F.
  4. Graphs C and D have the highest value for \(a\) because they have the same \(y\)-intercept.

answer.answer_text: Iâ€™d like to retry the self check.
Iâ€™m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 5.7.3: Describing Graphs
page.contents:
Activity

Your teacher will give you a set of cards containing descriptions of situations and graphs. Match each situation with a graph that represents it. Record your matches and be prepared to explain your reasoning.

Use the cards to answer questions 1â€“4. Match each graph representation to the description of the situation characterized by exponential change. Then choose the relationship between the number of years since purchase and the value.


  1. Choose the description of exponential change shown in the graph.

Correct! A car loses \(\frac14\) of its value every year after purchase.

Try again.

The correct answer is: A car loses \(\frac14\) of its value every year after purchase.


  1. Choose the description of exponential change shown in the graph.

Correct! The value of a stock triples roughly every 8 years.

Try again.

The correct answer is: The value of a stock triples roughly every 8 years.


  1. Choose the description of exponential change shown in the graph.

Correct! The value of a stock doubles approximately every 4 years.

Try again.

The correct answer is: The value of a stock doubles approximately every 4 years.


  1. Choose the description of exponential change shown in the graph.

Correct! A laptop loses \(\frac25\) of its value every year after purchase.

Try again.

The correct answer is: A laptop loses \(\frac25\) of its value every year after purchase.


Video: Analyzing Graphs of Exponential Scenarios

Watch the following video to learn more about how to analyze a graph to determine which exponential scenario it represents.

page.title: 5.7.3: Self Check
page.contents: Which scenario could be represented by the following graph?

answer.answer_text: A recent graduateâ€™s credit card balance started around $500 and increases at a rate of approximately 20% each month.
answer.response: Thatâ€™s correct! Check yourself: The labels show you are comparing money over time, and the initial value is around $500.

answer.answer_text: The population of sea birds started at 518 and is decreasing exponentially each month.
answer.response: Incorrect. Letâ€™s try again a different way: The graph shows exponential growth, but the situation is exponential decay. Also, the graphâ€™s labels are time and months. The answer is: A recent graduateâ€™s credit card balance starts around $500 and increases at a rate of approximately 20% each month.

answer.answer_text: The population of sea birds started at 518 and is increasing exponentially each month.
answer.response: Incorrect. Letâ€™s try again a different way: The graphâ€™s labels are time in months and total amount in dollars. The answer is: A recent graduateâ€™s credit card balance starts around $500 and increases at a rate of approximately 20% each month.

answer.answer_text: A recent graduateâ€™s credit card balance started around $500 and decreases at a rate of approximately 20% each month.
answer.response: Incorrect. Letâ€™s try again a different way: The graph shows exponential growth, but the situation is exponential decay. The answer is: A recent graduateâ€™s credit card balance starts around $500 and increases at a rate of approximately 20% each month.

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 5.7.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Connecting Exponential Situations and Graphs

Match each graph representation to the description of the situation characterized by exponential change.

Graph 1

   

Graph 2

Situation 1: A dangerous bacterial compound forms in a closed environment but is immediately detected. This bacteria is known to double in concentration in a closed environment every hour and can be modeled by the function \(P(t) = 100 \cdot 2^t\), where \(t\) is measured in hours.

Situation 2: Loggerhead turtles reproduce every 2 to 4 years, laying approximately 120 eggs in a clutch. Using this information, we can derive an approximate equation to model the turtle population. As is often the case in biological studies, we will count only the female turtles. If we start with a population of one female turtle in a protected area and assume that all turtles survive, we can roughly approximate the population of female turtles by \(P(t) = 5^t\). 

Since each graph represents exponential growth, and they both have the same labels, you have to look more closely at each. The biggest difference is the \(y\)-intercept or initial value. Graph 1 has an initial value of 100, and Graph 2 has a very small initial value. When you reread the situations, you can see that Situation 1 starts with 100 bacteria, and Situation 2 starts with 1 female turtle. This helps you see that Situation 1 belongs to Graph 1 and Situation 2 belongs to Graph 2.

Try It: Connecting Exponential Situations and Graphs

   

Write a possible situation for each graph. Make sure to include vocabulary about exponential functions.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

Here is how to write an exponential situation when given a graph:

First, determine if the function is growth or decay. If any points are provided, you can use them to determine the growth factor or initial value. Be sure to include the labels of the graph. Here are sample answers.

First, graph the number of people infected growing exponentially each week.

Second, graph the amount of medicine in the body starting at 80 mg and decaying by a factor of \(\frac14\) each hour.

answer.answer_text: Iâ€™d like to retry the self check.
Iâ€™m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 5.7.4: Quantities that Change Exponentially
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity


  1. This graph represents one of the following descriptions. Which one?
    1. A phone loses \(\frac45\) of its value every year after purchase; the relationship between the number of years since purchasing the phone and the value of the phone.
    2. The number of stores a company has tripled approximately every 5 years; the relationship between the number of years and the number of stores.
    3. A camera loses \(\frac25\) of its value every year after purchase; the relationship between the number of years since purchasing the camera and the value of the camera.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

A camera loses \(\frac25\) of its value every year after purchase; the relationship between the number of years since purchasing the camera and the value of the camera.



  1. Explain how you know the graph represents the description you chose.

Enter your answer here:

Your answers may vary, but here are some examples:

  • The graph cannot represent Description A because the phone is retaining only \(\frac15\) of its value, which is less than half, and the vertical coordinate of the second point on the graph is more than half of the vertical intercept.
  • If the camera loses \(\frac25\) of its value each year, then its value is \(\frac35\) that of the previous year. The vertical intercept seems to be 1,200, and \(\frac35\) of 1,200 is about 700, which is roughly the vertical coordinate of the second point.

page.title: 5.7.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. The two graphs show models characterized by exponential decay representing the area covered by two different algae blooms, in square yards, \(w\) weeks after different chemicals were applied.

    Which algae bloom covered a larger area when the chemicals were applied?

Correct! The algae bloom represented by the triangles because it has a higher \(y\)-intercept.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: The algae bloom represented by the triangles because it has a higher \(y\)-intercept. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. The two graphs show models characterized by exponential decay representing the area covered by two different algae blooms, in square yards, \(w\) weeks after different chemicals were applied.

    Which algae population is decreasing more rapidly? Explain how you know.

Correct! The algae bloom represented by the triangles because its graph is steeper.

Try again. Why donâ€™t you go back to activity 5.7.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is the algae bloom represented by the triangles because its graph is steeper. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. A medicine is applied to a burn on a patientâ€™s arm. The area of the burn in square centimeters decreases exponentially and is shown in the graph.

    What fraction of the burn area remains each week?

    Enter Answer Here: Enter your answer as a decimal not a fraction.

Correct! .75 or \(\frac34\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.7.1. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is .75 or \(\frac34\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. A medicine is applied to a burn on a patientâ€™s arm. The area of the burn in square centimeters decreases exponentially and is shown in the graph.

    Which of the following is an equation representing the area of the burn, \(a\), after \(t\) weeks?

Correct! \(a= 8 (\frac{3}{4})^t\)

Try again. Why donâ€™t you go back to activity 5.7.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(a= 8 (\frac{3}{4})^t\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. A medicine is applied to a burn on a patientâ€™s arm. The area of the burn in square centimeters decreases exponentially and is shown in the graph.

    What is the area of the burn after 7 weeks? Round to three decimal places.

Correct! 1.068

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.7.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 1.068. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. The graphs show the amounts of medicine in two patients after receiving injections. The circles show the medicine in patient A, and the triangles show the medicine in patient B.

    One equation that gives the amount of medicine in milligrams, \(m\), in patient A, \(h\) hours after an injection, is \(m=300(\frac{1}{2})^h\).

    What could be an equation for the amount of medicine in patient B?

Correct! \( m=200(\frac{7}{10})^h\)

Try again. Why donâ€™t you go back to activity 5.7.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \( m=200(\frac{7}{10})^h\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which scenario could describe the graph?


Correct! A population of bacteria doubles every hour and starts with 10 bacteria.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.7.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: A population of bacteria doubles every hour and starts with 10 bacteria. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which equation could represent the graph?


Correct!

Try again. Why donâ€™t you go back to activity 5.7.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(y= 2.104(1.479)^x\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Given a formula for an exponential function, is it possible to determine whether the function grows or decays exponentially just by looking at the formula? Explain.

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.7.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: Yes, if the growth rate is between zero and one, itâ€™s decay; if the growth rate is greater than one, itâ€™s growth. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 5.7.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Use graphs to compare and contrast situations that involve exponential decay.
  • Use information from a graph to write an equation that represents exponential decay.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 5.7.1: Patterns in Real Numbers
    • In this activity, you analyzed all the possible patterns connecting a set of numbers in a table. The numbers were written in both decimal and fraction form, and you may have noticed different patterns in each format.
  • 5.7.2: Comparing Graphs
    • In this activity, you looked at the graphs of the values of different cell phones over time. You were able to analyze each cell phone and compare them to one another by looking at key features of the graphs.
  • 5.7.2: Self Check 
  • 5.7.3: Describing Graphs 
    • In this activity, you connected the verbal description of a graph to the matching graph. Each description was a real-life scenario, and all of the graphs were exponential. You had to consider words that represent different growth rates and whether the situation was growth or decay.
  • 5.7.3: Self Check 
  • 5.7.4: Quantities that Change Exponentially
    • In this activity, you analyzed a graph and determined which of the scenarios provided it matches. It was a wrap up of all of the other skills from this lesson.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 5.7.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If youâ€™ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.

answer.answer_text: Previous
End of Lesson
